第1週：Gitとは？環境設定.title: Week 1: What is Git? Environment Setup
第1週：Gitとは？環境設定.description: Version control concepts, Git installation, initial configuration

Gitとは？.title: What is Git?
Gitとは？.content:
# What is Git?

**Git** is a distributed version control system developed by Linus Torvalds in 2005.

## What is Version Control?
A system for recording and managing change history of source code.

### Benefits
1. **History Management**: Records when, who, and what was changed
2. **Backup**: Can revert to previous states
3. **Parallel Development**: Multiple people can develop simultaneously
4. **Experimental Changes**: Safely test with branches

## Git Features
- **Distributed**: Each developer has a full copy
- **Fast**: Most operations complete locally
- **Lightweight Branches**: Easy to experiment and develop features
- **Data Integrity**: Managed with SHA-1 hash

## Difference between Git and GitHub
- **Git**: Version control system (tool)
- **GitHub**: Hosting service for Git repositories (web service)

Git初期設定.title: Git Initial Configuration
Git初期設定.content:
# Check Git version
git --version

# Set user information (required)
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"

# Set default branch name
git config --global init.defaultBranch main

# Set editor (optional)
git config --global core.editor "code --wait"

# Check configuration
git config --list
git config user.name
git config user.email

最初のリポジトリ作成.title: Create First Repository
最初のリポジトリ作成.content:
# Create new directory
mkdir my-first-repo
cd my-first-repo

# Initialize as Git repository
git init

# .git directory is created (hidden folder)
ls -la

# Create file
echo "# My First Repository" > README.md

# Check status
git status

subtasks.コミットメッセージの書き方を学習: Learn how to write commit messages

Gitの3つのエリア.title: Git's Three Areas
Gitの3つのエリア.content:
# Git's Three Areas

```
Working Directory → Staging Area → Repository
(Working Directory)  (Staging)     (Repository)
```

1. **Working Directory**: Where you edit files
2. **Staging Area**: Where you prepare changes for commit
3. **Repository**: Where committed history is stored

## Basic Workflow
```bash
# 1. Edit file
echo "Hello Git" > file.txt

# 2. Add to staging
git add file.txt

# 3. Commit (record to history)
git commit -m "Add file.txt"
```

git add - ステージング.title: git add - Staging
git add - ステージング.content:
# Stage specific file
git add README.md
git add src/main.js

# Stage multiple files
git add file1.txt file2.txt

# Stage all changes
git add .
git add -A

# Interactive mode
git add -i

# Patch mode (stage parts of changes)
git add -p

# Check staging status
git status

git commit - コミット.title: git commit - Commit
git commit - コミット.content:
# Basic commit
git commit -m "Add new feature"

# Multi-line commit message
git commit -m "Add user authentication" -m "- Implement login form" -m "- Add validation"

# Stage + commit simultaneously (tracked files only)
git commit -am "Update README"

# Write commit message in editor
git commit

# Amend previous commit
git commit --amend

# Empty commit (for testing, etc.)
git commit --allow-empty -m "Trigger CI"

git log - 履歴確認.title: git log - View History
git log - 履歴確認.content:
# Basic log display
git log

# Compact display (one line)
git log --oneline

# Graph display
git log --graph --oneline --all

# Show only latest N commits
git log -5
git log -n 3

# With statistics
git log --stat

# Show changes
git log -p
git log --patch

# Filter by author
git log --author="John"

# Filter by date
git log --since="2024-01-01"
git log --after="1 week ago"

# File history
git log README.md

# Custom format
git log --pretty=format:"%h - %an, %ar : %s"

良いコミットメッセージの書き方.title: How to Write Good Commit Messages
良いコミットメッセージの書き方.content:
# How to Write Good Commit Messages

## Basic Rules
1. **Line 1**: Summary within 50 characters (imperative)
2. **Line 2**: Blank line
3. **Line 3+**: Detailed description (wrap at 72 characters)

## Format Example
```
Add user authentication feature

- Implement login form with email/password
- Add JWT token generation
- Create auth middleware for protected routes
- Add input validation

Fixes #123
```

## Prefix Convention (Conventional Commits)
- `feat:` New feature
- `fix:` Bug fix
- `docs:` Documentation
- `style:` Code style
- `refactor:` Refactoring
- `test:` Add tests
- `chore:` Build, configuration changes

Example:
```
feat: add user profile page
fix: resolve login redirect issue
docs: update API documentation
```

ブランチとは？.title: What are Branches?
ブランチとは？.content:
# What are Branches?

Branches create independent development lines.

## Uses of Branches
1. **Feature Development**: Develop new features independently
2. **Bug Fixes**: Fix production issues
3. **Experiments**: Test experimental changes
4. **Releases**: Version management

## Branch Strategy
```
main (production)
  |
  |-- develop (development)
  |     |
  |     |-- feature/user-auth (Feature A)
  |     |-- feature/payment (Feature B)
  |
  |-- hotfix/critical-bug (Emergency fix)
```

## Default Branches
- **main** / **master**: For production
- **develop**: For development
- **feature/xxx**: For feature development

ブランチ操作.title: Branch Operations
ブランチ操作.content:
# List branches
git branch
git branch -a  # Also show remote branches

# Create new branch
git branch feature/login
git branch develop

# Switch branch
git checkout feature/login
git checkout develop

# Create + switch (simultaneous)
git checkout -b feature/payment
git checkout -b hotfix/bug-123

# New command (Git 2.23+)
git switch feature/login  # Switch
git switch -c feature/new  # Create + switch

# Rename branch
git branch -m old-name new-name

# Delete branch
git branch -d feature/login  # Merged only
git branch -D feature/login  # Force delete

マージ.title: Merge
マージ.content:
# Basic merge (Fast-forward)
git checkout main
git merge feature/login

# Create merge commit (--no-ff)
git merge --no-ff feature/payment

# Abort merge
git merge --abort

# Check merged branches
git branch --merged
git branch --no-merged

# Example: Feature development flow
# 1. Create new branch
git checkout -b feature/user-profile

# 2. Develop & commit
git add .
git commit -m "Add user profile page"

# 3. Return to main branch
git checkout main

# 4. Merge
git merge feature/user-profile

# 5. Delete branch
git branch -d feature/user-profile

コンフリクト（競合）解消.title: Conflict Resolution
コンフリクト（競合）解消.content:
# When conflict occurs
$ git merge feature/payment
Auto-merging file.txt
CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in file.txt
Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result.

# Check conflict files
git status

# Conflict markers in file
<<<<<<< HEAD
This is the content from current branch
=======
This is the content from branch being merged
>>>>>>> feature/payment

# Resolution steps:
# 1. Manually edit file and remove markers
# 2. Decide which changes to keep
# 3. Stage
git add file.txt

# 4. Complete merge commit
git commit

# Abort conflict resolution
git merge --abort

# Use merge tool
git mergetool

第4週：GitHubとリモートリポジトリ.title: Week 4: GitHub and Remote Repositories
第4週：GitHubとリモートリポジトリ.description: GitHub account setup, creating remote repositories

GitHubとは？.title: What is GitHub?
GitHubとは？.content:
# What is GitHub?

**GitHub** is a hosting service for Git repositories.

## Main GitHub Features
1. **Repository Hosting**: Store code in the cloud
2. **Collaboration**: Develop with teams
3. **Issue Management**: Track bugs and feature requests
4. **Pull Request**: Code review
5. **GitHub Actions**: CI/CD automation
6. **GitHub Pages**: Website hosting
7. **Project Management**: Kanban boards

## GitHub Competitors
- **GitLab**: Self-hosting possible
- **Bitbucket**: Integrates with Atlassian products
- **Azure Repos**: Microsoft product

## Public vs Private
- **Public**: Anyone can view (open source)
- **Private**: Only invited people can view

SSH認証設定.title: SSH Authentication Setup
SSH認証設定.content:
# Generate SSH key
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your.email@example.com"

# Copy SSH key to clipboard (Mac)
pbcopy < ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

# Copy SSH key to clipboard (Windows)
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub | clip

# Copy SSH key to clipboard (Linux)
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub | xclip -selection clipboard

# GitHub > Settings > SSH and GPG keys > New SSH key
# Enter title and paste key

# Test connection
ssh -T git@github.com
# Success: "Hi username! You've successfully authenticated..."

リモートリポジトリ操作.title: Remote Repository Operations
リモートリポジトリ操作.content:
# Clone existing repository
git clone https://github.com/username/repo.git
git clone git@github.com:username/repo.git  # SSH

# Clone specific branch
git clone -b develop https://github.com/username/repo.git

# Add remote repository
git remote add origin https://github.com/username/repo.git

# Check remote repositories
git remote -v

# Remote repository details
git remote show origin

# Change remote repository URL
git remote set-url origin git@github.com:username/repo.git

# Remove remote repository
git remote remove origin

# Multiple remotes
git remote add upstream https://github.com/original/repo.git
git remote add origin https://github.com/myname/repo.git

subtasks.pullとfetchの違いを理解: Understand difference between pull and fetch

git push - アップロード.title: git push - Upload
git push - アップロード.content:
# Basic push
git push origin main
git push origin develop

# First push (set upstream branch)
git push -u origin main
git push --set-upstream origin feature/login

# Can be omitted afterwards
git push

# Push all branches
git push --all

# Push tags
git push --tags
git push origin v1.0.0

# Force push (dangerous!)
git push -f origin main
git push --force-with-lease origin main  # Safer

# Delete branch
git push origin --delete feature/old-branch
git push origin :feature/old-branch  # Old syntax

git pull - ダウンロード + マージ.title: git pull - Download + Merge
git pull - ダウンロード + マージ.content:
# Basic pull (fetch + merge)
git pull origin main

# If upstream branch is set
git pull

# Pull with rebase
git pull --rebase origin main

# Fetch all remote branches
git pull --all

# Example: Team development flow
# 1. Get latest before work
git pull origin main

# 2. Development work
git add .
git commit -m "Add feature"

# 3. Pull again before pushing
git pull origin main

# 4. Resolve conflicts if any

# 5. Push
git push origin main

git fetch - ダウンロードのみ.title: git fetch - Download Only
git fetch - ダウンロードのみ.content:
# Fetch remote changes (don't merge)
git fetch origin

# Fetch specific branch
git fetch origin main

# Fetch from all remotes
git fetch --all

# Reflect deleted remote branches
git fetch --prune
git fetch -p

# Difference between fetch and pull
# git pull = git fetch + git merge

# Safe update flow
# 1. Fetch only first
git fetch origin main

# 2. Check differences
git diff main origin/main
git log main..origin/main

# 3. Merge if no issues
git merge origin/main

# Or pull from the start
git pull origin main

PullとFetchの違い.title: Difference between Pull and Fetch
PullとFetchの違い.content:
# Difference between Pull and Fetch

## git fetch
- **Download only** remote changes
- Local branch is not changed
- Can safely check differences

```bash
git fetch origin
git diff main origin/main  # Check differences
git merge origin/main      # Manually merge
```

## git pull
- **Download + merge** remote changes
- Combination of `git fetch` + `git merge`
- Automatically merged

```bash
git pull origin main
# = git fetch origin main + git merge origin/main
```

## Which to Use?
- **Beginners**: `git pull` is OK
- **Cautious**: `git fetch` → check → `git merge`
- **Team Development**: `git pull --rebase` to keep history clean

## pull --rebase
```bash
git pull --rebase origin main
```
Keeps history linear without merge commits.

第6週：プルリクエストとコードレビュー.title: Week 6: Pull Requests and Code Review
第6週：プルリクエストとコードレビュー.description: Creating pull requests, code review process

Pull Requestとは？.title: What is a Pull Request?
Pull Requestとは？.content:
# What is a Pull Request?

**Pull Request (PR)** is a request to have others review your changes and merge them.

## PR Benefits
1. **Code Review**: Find bugs and best practice violations
2. **Knowledge Sharing**: Team understands the code
3. **Quality Improvement**: Checked by multiple eyes
4. **Discussion Forum**: Discuss implementation approaches

## PR Workflow
```
1. Create branch
   git checkout -b feature/new-feature

2. Develop & commit
   git add .
   git commit -m "Add new feature"

3. Push
   git push origin feature/new-feature

4. Create PR on GitHub
   - Enter title and description
   - Specify reviewers

5. Review & Fix
   - Address feedback
   - Add commits

6. Merge
   - Merge after review approval

7. Delete branch
   git branch -d feature/new-feature
```

良いPRの書き方.title: How to Write Good PRs
良いPRの書き方.content:
# How to Write Good Pull Requests

## Title
- Concise and clear about content
- Example: `Add user authentication feature`
- Example: `Fix login redirect bug #123`

## Description
```markdown
## Overview
Added user authentication feature.

## Changes
- Implemented login form
- Added JWT authentication
- Created auth middleware
- Added validation

## Tests
- [ ] Login success case
- [ ] Login failure case
- [ ] Token expiration

## Screenshots
(If UI changes)

## Related Issues
Fixes #123
Closes #124
```

## PR Size
- **Smaller is better**: Easier to review
- **1 PR per feature/fix**
- Ideal: under 500 lines

## Self Review
Review your own code before creating PR.

PR作成の流れ.title: PR Creation Flow
PR作成の流れ.content:
# 1. Create new branch
git checkout -b feature/user-profile

# 2. Development work
# ... write code ...

# 3. Commit
git add .
git commit -m "feat: add user profile page"

# 4. Push to remote
git push -u origin feature/user-profile

# 5. Create PR on GitHub
# https://github.com/username/repo/pull/new/feature/user-profile
# Or click link shown in browser

# 6. Address review comments
# ... make fixes ...
git add .
git commit -m "refactor: improve validation logic"
git push

# 7. After merge, delete local branch
git checkout main
git pull
git branch -d feature/user-profile

# 8. Delete remote branch too (can be auto-deleted on GitHub)
git push origin --delete feature/user-profile

GitHub Issues.title: GitHub Issues
GitHub Issues.content:
# GitHub Issues

**Issues** are used for bug reports, feature requests, and task management.

## Issue Types
1. **Bug Report**: Report bugs
2. **Feature Request**: Propose new features
3. **Question**: Ask questions
4. **Task**: Task management

## Issue Template Example
```markdown
## Bug Description
Login button doesn't respond when clicked

## Reproduction Steps
1. Open login page
2. Enter email and password
3. Click login button

## Expected Behavior
Redirect to dashboard

## Actual Behavior
Nothing happens

## Environment
- OS: Windows 11
- Browser: Chrome 120
```

## Issue and PR Integration
```bash
# Reference Issue in commit message
git commit -m "Fix login button, refs #123"

# Close Issue in PR
# Add to PR description:
Fixes #123
Closes #124
Resolves #125
```

第7週：Rebase、Stash、Reset.title: Week 7: Rebase, Stash, Reset
第7週：Rebase、Stash、Reset.description: Advanced Git operations for history management

git rebase - 履歴を整理.title: git rebase - Organize History
git rebase - 履歴を整理.content:
# Basic rebase
git checkout feature
git rebase main

# Interactive rebase (edit past commits)
git rebase -i HEAD~3  # Edit latest 3 commits

# Commands available during rebase:
# pick: Use commit as is
# reword: Change commit message
# edit: Edit commit
# squash: Combine with previous commit
# fixup: Combine with previous commit (discard message)
# drop: Delete commit

# Example: Combine multiple commits into one
git rebase -i HEAD~4
# pick abc123 Add feature A
# squash def456 Fix typo
# squash ghi789 Update tests
# squash jkl012 Fix bug

# Abort rebase
git rebase --abort

# Continue rebase (after resolving conflicts)
git add .
git rebase --continue

# Skip rebase
git rebase --skip

MergeとRebaseの違い.title: Difference between Merge and Rebase
MergeとRebaseの違い.content:
# Difference between Merge and Rebase

## git merge
```
main:     A---B---C---F (merge commit)
               \       /
feature:        D---E
```
- Creates merge commit
- History branches
- All history is preserved
- **Safe** and easy to understand

## git rebase
```
main:     A---B---C
feature:              D'---E'
```
- Makes history linear
- Clean history
- Commits are rewritten
- **Simple history**

## Which to Use?
- **Merge**: Published branches, team development
- **Rebase**: Your own branches, when you want clean history

## ⚠️ Warning
**Don't rebase pushed commits!**
It confuses team members.

git stash - 一時保存.title: git stash - Temporary Save
git stash - 一時保存.content:
# Temporarily save current work
git stash
git stash save "Work in progress on feature X"

# Include untracked files
git stash -u
git stash --include-untracked

# List stashes
git stash list
# stash@{0}: WIP on main: abc123 Latest commit
# stash@{1}: On feature: def456 Old work

# Apply stash (don't delete)
git stash apply
git stash apply stash@{1}

# Apply stash and delete
git stash pop
git stash pop stash@{0}

# Show stash contents
git stash show
git stash show -p stash@{0}

# Delete stash
git stash drop stash@{0}
git stash clear  # Delete all

# Practical example:
# 1. Urgent bug fix needed while working
git stash  # Save current work
git checkout -b hotfix/critical-bug
# ... fix bug ...
git checkout feature
git stash pop  # Resume work

git reset vs git revert.title: git reset vs git revert
git reset vs git revert.content:
# git reset - Undo commit (rewrite history)
# --soft: Only undo commit (changes remain staged)
git reset --soft HEAD~1

# --mixed (default): Undo commit + staging
git reset HEAD~1
git reset --mixed HEAD~1

# --hard: Undo everything (dangerous!)
git reset --hard HEAD~1

# Reset to specific commit
git reset --hard abc123

# git revert - Create revert commit (preserve history)
git revert HEAD  # Revert latest commit
git revert abc123  # Revert specific commit

# Revert multiple commits
git revert HEAD~3..HEAD

# When to use reset vs revert
# - Before push: reset is OK
# - After push: use revert (safe)

# Reset specific file
git reset HEAD file.txt  # Unstage
git checkout -- file.txt  # Discard changes

第8週：タグ、Cherry-pick、高度なテクニック.title: Week 8: Tags, Cherry-pick, Advanced Techniques
第8週：タグ、Cherry-pick、高度なテクニック.description: Tag management, cherry-pick, advanced Git techniques

git tag - バージョン管理.title: git tag - Version Management
git tag - バージョン管理.content:
# Lightweight tag
git tag v1.0.0
git tag v1.1.0

# Annotated tag (recommended)
git tag -a v1.0.0 -m "Version 1.0.0 release"
git tag -a v2.0.0 -m "Major update with breaking changes"

# List tags
git tag
git tag -l "v1.*"  # Pattern search

# Show tag details
git show v1.0.0

# Tag past commit
git tag -a v0.9.0 abc123 -m "Beta release"

# Push tags
git push origin v1.0.0  # Specific tag
git push origin --tags  # All tags

# Checkout tag
git checkout v1.0.0

# Delete tag
git tag -d v1.0.0  # Local
git push origin --delete v1.0.0  # Remote

# Semantic Versioning
# v1.2.3
#  | | └─ Patch: Bug fixes
#  | └─── Minor: Feature additions (backward compatible)
#  └───── Major: Breaking changes

git cherry-pick.title: git cherry-pick
git cherry-pick.content:
# Pick specific commit only
git cherry-pick abc123

# Multiple commits
git cherry-pick abc123 def456 ghi789

# Commit range
git cherry-pick abc123..def456

# Conflict during cherry-pick
git cherry-pick abc123
# ... resolve conflict ...
git add .
git cherry-pick --continue

# Abort cherry-pick
git cherry-pick --abort

# Practical example:
# Apply bug fix from hotfix branch to develop
git checkout develop
git cherry-pick abc123  # Pick commit from hotfix

便利なGitコマンド.title: Useful Git Commands
便利なGitコマンド.content:
# git blame - Show last editor of each line
git blame file.txt
git blame -L 10,20 file.txt  # Lines 10-20 only

# git diff - Show differences
git diff  # Working directory vs staging
git diff --staged  # Staging vs repository
git diff HEAD  # Working directory vs latest commit
git diff main..feature  # Differences between branches
git diff abc123 def456  # Differences between commits
git diff --stat  # Statistics only

# git show - Show commit contents
git show abc123
git show HEAD~2
git show v1.0.0

# git reflog - All operation history
git reflog
git reflog show HEAD

# Recovery after accidental reset
git reflog
git reset --hard abc123  # Return to commit found in reflog

# git clean - Delete untracked files
git clean -n  # Check files to be deleted (dry run)
git clean -f  # Execute deletion
git clean -fd  # Also delete directories

# git bisect - Find commit that introduced bug
git bisect start
git bisect bad  # Current has bug
git bisect good abc123  # This commit was OK
# ... automatically narrows down with binary search ...
git bisect reset  # Finish

第9週：ブランチ戦略とチーム開発.title: Week 9: Branch Strategy and Team Development
第9週：ブランチ戦略とチーム開発.description: Git Flow, GitHub Flow, collaboration strategies

Git Flow.title: Git Flow
Git Flow.content:
# Git Flow

Git Flow is a branching model proposed by Vincent Driessen.

## Branch Types

### Permanent Branches
1. **main (master)**: For production
2. **develop**: Main branch for development

### Temporary Branches
3. **feature/xxx**: New feature development
4. **release/x.x.x**: Release preparation
5. **hotfix/xxx**: Emergency bug fixes

## Workflow

```
main ─────●─────────────●─────────●──
          │             ↑         ↑
          │        release/1.1  hotfix/bug
          ↓             │         │
develop ──●─────●───●───●─────────●──
              ↗   ↗   ↘
        feature/ feature/ feature/
          A        B        C
```

## Usage

### New Feature Development
```bash
# Branch from develop
git checkout develop
git checkout -b feature/user-auth
# Develop...
git checkout develop
git merge --no-ff feature/user-auth
git branch -d feature/user-auth
```

### Release
```bash
git checkout -b release/1.0.0 develop
# Bug fixes, version number updates
git checkout main
git merge --no-ff release/1.0.0
git tag -a v1.0.0
git checkout develop
git merge --no-ff release/1.0.0
```

### Hotfix
```bash
git checkout -b hotfix/critical-bug main
# Fix...
git checkout main
git merge --no-ff hotfix/critical-bug
git tag -a v1.0.1
git checkout develop
git merge --no-ff hotfix/critical-bug
```

GitHub Flow.title: GitHub Flow
GitHub Flow.content:
# GitHub Flow

Simple workflow recommended by GitHub.

## Features
- **Single main branch**: Only main
- **Continuous Deployment**: Deploy frequently
- **Simple**: Easier than Git Flow

## Workflow

```
main ──●─────────●─────────●─────────●──
        ↘       ↗  ↘      ↗  ↘       ↗
      feature/A  feature/B  feature/C
```

## Steps

### 1. Create Branch
```bash
git checkout -b feature/new-button
```

### 2. Add Commits
```bash
git add .
git commit -m "Add new button"
git push origin feature/new-button
```

### 3. Create Pull Request
Create PR on GitHub

### 4. Review & Discuss
Team members review

### 5. Deploy and Test
Test in staging environment

### 6. Merge to main
Merge PR → Auto deploy

## Git Flow vs GitHub Flow

| | Git Flow | GitHub Flow |
|---|---|---|
| **Complexity** | Complex | Simple |
| **Branches** | 5 types | 2 types |
| **Best for** | Scheduled releases | Continuous deployment |
| **Team** | Large | Small to medium |
| **Release** | Version management | Always latest |

フォークとコラボレーション.title: Fork and Collaboration
フォークとコラボレーション.content:
# Fork and Collaboration

## Collaborator Model
Has direct access to repository

```bash
# 1. Clone
git clone git@github.com:team/project.git

# 2. Create branch
git checkout -b feature/my-work

# 3. Push
git push origin feature/my-work

# 4. Create PR
```

## Fork Model (Open Source)
Copy to your account and work

### Steps

1. **Fork on GitHub**
   - Click "Fork" button on original repository

2. **Clone**
```bash
git clone git@github.com:myname/project.git
cd project
```

3. **Add upstream**
```bash
git remote add upstream git@github.com:original/project.git
git remote -v
# origin: Your fork
# upstream: Original repository
```

4. **Create branch & work**
```bash
git checkout -b feature/my-contribution
# ... develop ...
git push origin feature/my-contribution
```

5. **Create PR**
   - PR from your fork to original repository

6. **Get upstream changes**
```bash
git fetch upstream
git checkout main
git merge upstream/main
git push origin main
```

## Which to Use?
- **Collaborator**: Private, team development
- **Fork**: Open source, external contributors

第10週：.gitignore、GitHub Actions、ベストプラクティス.title: Week 10: .gitignore, GitHub Actions, Best Practices
第10週：.gitignore、GitHub Actions、ベストプラクティス.description: .gitignore configuration, GitHub Actions basics, best practices

.gitignore.title: .gitignore
.gitignore.content:
# .gitignore - Specify files to ignore

# OS-specific files
.DS_Store        # macOS
Thumbs.db        # Windows

# Editors
.vscode/
.idea/
*.swp
*.swo

# Dependencies
node_modules/
vendor/
__pycache__/
*.pyc

# Build artifacts
build/
dist/
*.exe
*.o
*.class

# Environment variables & config files
.env
.env.local
config.local.js

# Log files
*.log
logs/

# Databases
*.sqlite
*.db

# Patterns
# All txt files
*.txt

# Exception: Track README.txt
!README.txt

# Entire directory
temp/

# Nested patterns
**/node_modules/

# Set global .gitignore
git config --global core.excludesfile ~/.gitignore_global

# .gitignore generator
# https://gitignore.io

GitHub Actions基礎.title: GitHub Actions Basics
GitHub Actions基礎.content:
# .github/workflows/ci.yml
name: CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [ main, develop ]
  pull_request:
    branches: [ main ]

jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v3
    
    - name: Setup Node.js
      uses: actions/setup-node@v3
      with:
        node-version: '18'
    
    - name: Install dependencies
      run: npm install
    
    - name: Run tests
      run: npm test
    
    - name: Run linter
      run: npm run lint

  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: test
    
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v3
    
    - name: Build
      run: npm run build
    
    - name: Upload artifact
      uses: actions/upload-artifact@v3
      with:
        name: build-files
        path: dist/

Gitのベストプラクティス.title: Git Best Practices
Gitのベストプラクティス.content:
# Git Best Practices

## Commits
1. **Small and frequent**: Commit per feature/fix
2. **Meaningful units**: Group related changes
3. **Good messages**: Clearly state what and why changed
4. **Commit working code**: Avoid build errors

## Branches
1. **Protect main/develop**: Don't push directly
2. **Branch per feature**: feature/xxx
3. **Keep short-lived**: Don't leave for long periods
4. **Naming convention**: Maintain consistency

## Pull Requests
1. **Small PRs**: Easy to review size
2. **Detailed description**: Background, changes, testing methods
3. **Self review**: Check yourself first
4. **Pass CI**: After tests succeed

## Code Review
1. **Constructive**: Clear improvement suggestions
2. **Quick**: Within 24 hours
3. **Ask questions**: Ask if you don't understand
4. **Approval criteria**: Make clear

## Don'ts
1. ❌ Rebase pushed commits
2. ❌ Push directly to main branch
3. ❌ Too large commits
4. ❌ Meaningless commit messages (only "fix", "update")
5. ❌ Commit passwords or secret keys
6. ❌ Use `git push -f` on production branch

## Useful Aliases
```bash
git config --global alias.st status
git config --global alias.co checkout
git config --global alias.br branch
git config --global alias.ci commit
git config --global alias.unstage 'reset HEAD --'
git config --global alias.last 'log -1 HEAD'
git config --global alias.lg "log --graph --oneline --all"
```
